fields.label_text:
Leg from a stool or chair
About 200–395 AD

Egypt
Turned acacia with traces of paint

Museum no. 536-1891

Wood turning was widely practised in Egypt at this period, and possibly much earlier. Many intricately turned legs from stools, chairs, beds and couches have survived in the dry soils of burial sites. The complex and confident profiles of this single-piece leg were turned on a horizontal pole lathe.

fields.physical_description:
Stool leg turned from a single piece of wood (not yet identified). Its profile is made up of a series of turnings, consisting, from the top down, of a squashed bulb shape, a large tapering reel, a smaller reel, a convex cap, and a longer tapering reel terminating in a plain foot. Underneath the foot there is a lathe mark. There are traces of paint, including, near the top, a green (atacamite, a traditional green pigment used since antiquity until modern times) and lower down off-white, but not enough paint survives to suggest what the original scheme was. 

Wood identification Acacia sp., acacia was carried out October 2012 by Dr Caroline Cartright, wood anatomist (scientist) at the British Museum.
fields.label:
Leg from a stool or chair
About 200–395 AD

Egypt
Turned acacia with traces of paint

Museum no. 536-1891

Wood turning was widely practised in Egypt at this period, and possibly much earlier. Many intricately turned legs from stools, chairs, beds and couches have survived in the dry soils of burial sites. The complex and confident profiles of this single-piece leg were turned on a horizontal pole lathe. 
 [01/12/2012]
fields.location: Furniture, room 133, case BY1, shelf EXP
fields.object: Leg from a stool or chair
fields.public_access_description:
This Egypto-Roman leg probably comes from a stool. It was purchased from W. M. Flinders Petrie in 1891 with a group of ancient Egyptian objects, and appears to have come from Kom-Ioushim or Rubaiyat, north-east of the Fayûm, Middle Egypt.

An indentation on the underside of the leg marks where the leg was held on the spindle of a pole lathe, for turning. The art of wood turning became widely practiced in Egypt during the Greco-Roman Period (ca. 332 BC-641 AD). Ball, spool, and vase profiles were turned on light, vertical lathes to produce legs for stools, chairs, beds or couch legs, which are often finished with bell-shaped feet. The complex baluster profiles on this leg indicate that it was produced using a heavier, horizontally mounted pole lathe which was developed during the Roman Period (ca. 30 BC-395 AD).
fields.history_note:
Purchased from W.M. Flinders Petrie, item number 98, 'leg, turned, wood', in a list of 123 Ancient Egyptian objects, Agenda No. 3447, 29th September 1891:
Objects received from: W. M. Flinders Petrie, 8 Crescent Rd., Bromley, Kent, total cost £9.16

This leg was one of 7 turned legs of chairs measuring between 10-22 inches, dated by Petrie as Roman. III-IV century A.D. In a letter dated 12 Sept 1891 he offered a collection of woodwork to the Museum, explaining: '	While in Egypt this spring the Arabs were plundering the Roman towns in the Fayum, & they brought me pieces of furniture, & other things out of the line of the dealers. As I know that no one will take the trouble to bring over such bulky things as a matter of business, I thought it was perhaps the only chance of securing them, & I brought several pieces of joinery & carving.' 

This leg probably came from a stool. The lathe mark on the bottom of the leg demonstrates that it was turned on a pole lathe. The complex baluster shape required a high level of skill. Petrie's finds appear to have come from Karanis (modern Kom Aushim) or  Rubaiyat (modern Philadelphia/Kom el-Kharaba el-Kebir), NE of Faiyum, Middle Egypt.
fields.production_note: Karanis (modern Kom Aushim) or  Rubaiyat (modern Philadelphia/Kom el-Kharaba el-Kebir), NE of Faiyum, Middle Egypt
fields.historical_context_note:
Although wood turning in Egypt is considered to be a Greco-Roman (ca. 332 BC- 641 AD) development, there is the possibility that it was practiced much earlier. For example, evidence of turning can be found on a pair of early New Kingdom (ca. 1550-1070 BC) stools in the British Museum, both of which are symmetrical in profile and have clear pivot holes on the bottom of their feet. However, the assumption that wood turning was practiced in the New Kingdom is still being investigated by scholars. 

The first proven example of wood turning in Egypt, using a lathe, is seen in a relief found in the Ptolemaic tomb of Petosiris at Tuna el-Gebel, which dates to the regency of Philip Arrhidaeus (323-305 BC) in the Greco-Roman Period. It shows a pair of carpenters turning a wooden leg, using a simple vertical lathe constructed of a pillar set into the ground. The turned leg, which is supported on pivots between top and bottom stocks,
is being rotated back and forth by one man with a length of rope, while the other man scrapes the wood away with a chisel. The scraping, accomplished by Egyptian turners using flat-blade scrapers or angled skew chisels, was done on both the forward and reverse motion of the work, resulting in chatter and score marks being left on the wood.  

The art of wood turning, using the type of lathe illustrated in the tomb of Petosiris, became widely practiced in Egypt during the Greco-Roman Period. Many intricately turned furniture legs date to this period; they are elegantly worked into ball, spool, and vase profiles, to produce objects such as stool, chair, bed, or couch legs, often finished with bell-shaped feet. This type of turned leg can be seen painted on Greek vases and on Roman wall frescos, indicating the desirability of this type of furniture in the Greco-Roman period.  

Although prevalent, this type of light, vertical lathe would not have been able to produce the heavier, more intricately turned legs of the Roman period (ca. 30 BC-395 AD). Horizontally mounted pole lathes had to be developed to produce the more complex profile seen in legs such as 536-1891 at the V&A.

References  
Killen, G.P., "Furniture" and "Woodworking," in The Oxford Encyclopaedia of Ancient Egypt (New York, 2001), 516-519 and 580-586  
Killen, G.P.,  "Woodworking," in ed. Paul T. Nicholson and Ian Shaw, Ancient Egyptian Materials and Technology (Cambridge, 2000), 353-371  
Killen, G.P., Ancient Egyptian Furniture, Volume II, Boxes, Chests and Footstools (Warminster Wiltshire, 1994)  
Killen, Geoffrey, Egyptian Woodworking and Furniture (Buckinghamshire, 1994)
Killen, G.P., Ancient Egyptian Furniture, Volume I, 4000-1300 BC (Warminster Wiltshire, 1980) 
"Egyptian Furniture" http://pcwww.liv.ac.uk/~killen/history.htm, 1-4 accessed 11/01/2011  
 "Woodworking" http://pcwww.liv.ac.uk/~killen/history.htm, 1-4 accessed 11/01/2011
